newsitem.title: CANADA: BANK OF CANADA TO AUCTION C$500 MLN 356-DAY BILLS.
newsitem.headline: BANK OF CANADA TO AUCTION C$500 MLN 356-DAY BILLS.

text.p: The Bank of Canada plans to auction C$500 million of 356-day treasury bills today, the central bank said on Wednesday.
The bills will be dated and delivered on August 15 and will mature on August 6, 1998, the Bank of Canada said.
Tenders will be received no later than 1130 EDT/1530 GMT today and results will be released at 1215 EDT/1615 GMT today.

The reopening of the one-year T-bill comes after trading of the issue was distorted by a major squeeze which came to light following yesterday's auction, dealers said. The Bank of Canada yesterday sold C$1.0 billion of T-bills due August 6, which produced an average yield 3.886 percent.
Dealers said there is speculation a major U.S. player was responsible for the squeeze.
While the central bank's decision to reopen the issue was seen as positive, dealers said it may not be enough to cover to meet the market's needs.

"The issue's too small. I know of C$600 million (owing) myself so C$500 million is not going to satisfy that, and it still leaves the door open for it to be scooped," said one T-bill dealer with a bank-owned brokerage. "The participants that own the present issue will probably come back and rebid for this issue."
The dealer said market participants recommended to the central bank that it reopen the issue and were pleased that it happened.

"It will help. I think the street is short more than the C$500 million but it will make a difference," said another T-bill trader with a bank-owned brokerage. "It's a very positive thing for the bank to do, and I think it will help for down the road."
The one-year T-bill due August 6, 1998 traded with a yield of 3.72 percent after the reopening was announced, compared with a yield of 3.95 percent at the close of trading on Tuesday.
